text: EXTREMELY WIDE SHOT: Fog. Nothing else in sight. Slowly, SMALL STEAM BOAT emerges: A LIGHTHOUSE TENDER. It chugs along, a tiny blip in a vast ocean. Black smoke puffs fro its crooked chimney. Its old engine sputters softly. Hold. The FOGHORN again, louder now. Closer.
CLOSE ON: The rotten, rusty prow carves through the waves The third-rate engine rumbles. Hold.

WIDE: SHADOWS stand on the bow of the boat (back to CAMER They might be men, but they could just as easily be ghost THE FOGHORN BLASTS. It’s close enough to feel. A FLASH OF LIGHT breaks through the fog, revealing... The silhouette of a bleak stone island, no bigger than an acre: PILOT ROCK. A few ramshackle outbuildings cling to surface like barnacles. On the highest point of the islan stands a tall, crumbling LIGHTHOUSE TOWER. An ominous flo of SEAGULLS screech and caw around it. THE FOGHORN and LIGHT bellow and flash again. THE ISLAND itself seems to draw the boat and the men clos

It’s dark in the fog, even with the flashing light above. A TRANSFER BOAT is beached on the shore. TWO RELIEF MATES doll out provisions to TWO MEN in dark uniforms and caps. hand-over is challenging.  The TWO UNIFORMED MEN come in and out of view, carrying supplies. One lags behind, carrying the heavier load. They walk past a small, dilapidated BOATHOUSE with no doo poorly mended DORY -- THE LIFE BOAT -- is tied up inside, sitting on the twisted runners of the launch that stretch into the lapping waves.

location: PILOT ROCK. NEAR THE LIVING QUARTERS

text: TWO OTHER MEN (late 60s, same uniforms) exit the one-stor CLAPBOARD SHACK that adjoins THE LIGHTHOUSE by a remarkab long breezeway. They are the departing LIGHTHOUSE KEEPERS “WICKIES,” as they refer to themselves. They lug gunny sa over their shoulders, and drag their rope-handled ditty b by their sides, keeping their heads down. Their bearded f are craggy and leaden. They reek of tobacco, must, and sa They shuffle toward their relief: THE MEN FROM THE TENDER carrying their supplies. The four almost exchange glances. But they don’t bother. THE FOGHORN bellows.

location: PILOT ROCK. NEAR THE LIVING QUARTERS

text: The new wickies stand utterly still, next to each other, their gazes fixed on the same distant spot. One man is YOUNG (early 30s). Tall, athletic -- but starv His deep set eyes are haunted, and his left eye is healin from a week-old shiner. His crooked expression is severe. There’s an eerie disquiet about him. He’s like a dog that been beaten and caged too many times. A small mustache sh his vanity. The other is OLD (Haggard 60? Spry 70?). He’s weathered, feral bearded, and hunched, with hands like vises. His la of visible lips suggests some missing teeth. He tremors a bit, but he’s lean and sturdy as a lead pipe. His high cheekbones smile even when he grimaces. His wild eyes shi like jewels. He’s an old Pan. A Satyr. Both of them seem like the kind of man you might find muttering to himself in the corner of an empty bar room w a distant look in his eye. They watch THE TENDER depart the island, ever-so-slowly disappearing -- swallowed up again by the fog.  THE FOGHORN bellows louder than ever, penetrating deep through the bodies of the two men. IT SHAKES THE YOUNG MA shocks him - but not the OLD one. He’s used to it. OLD puts the stump of an unlit clay PIPE in his mouth (up down). He lumbers out of frame, limping a bit, and happy finally be “home again.” YOUNG stays standing, staring out. A bit of fear strikes There’s no turning back now.

YOUNG throws down his heavy supplies. They thud against the warped, mildewed floorboards. He walks through the kitchen and takes a look around... It’s run-down and spare: A coal range, a farmhouse sink w a water pump by the sole window, a small cupboard, a tabl and two chairs. The wind blows. It’s depressing. He keeps walking. He hears the sound of dribbling water (0.S.)...

Entering the parlor, he sees: A reed splint rocker with a busted seat, a rattling potbelly stove, and a small, very dusty, government issue book chest. A CLOCK ticks monotonously. Then, YOUNG spots a fine DESK with a ship in a bottle on It’s rolled shut. He looks around, shifty eyed, to be sur one is watching him... Instinctively, he passes his hand along the top of the de to the LOCK. He jiggles it. Locked. Damn. Then, there is that persistent sound of dribbling water (O.S.)...
The sound grows louder as he climbs the narrow stairs, ev tread creaking along the way. The dribbling grows louder.  He enters the sleeping quarters...
THUD! YOUNG bumps his head on the low ceiling...

(under his breath) Son-of-a-- He shakes it off... The bunkroom is also dismal. Not much more than two saggi cast-iron single beds. OLD stands near his bed, PISSING INTO HIS CHAMBER POT. Pause. YOUNG absorbs the scene. YOUNG walks to the unoccupied bed and sits down. As soon he does, OLD FARTS about three feet away from YOUNG’S fac deliberate display of power.

Pause. OLD finishes relieving himself. He shakes his member. He buttons up, and kicks the pot under his bed. The piss nea sloshes out. Mercifully, it doesn’t. OLD limps away whistling (the song “Tis Brasswork”). He pauses briefly... FARTS again. He leaves frame, his UNEVEN GAIT disappearing: Walk-drag, walk-drag, walk-drag... YOUNG sits on his bed. Still. Simmering. He’s not pleased But he'll try to keep that to himself. He holds his head. The CLOCK from downstairs ticks... Just then, YOUNG feels something strange under him... He feels around... He discovers a hole in the mattress. Something is poking out... He digs his finger into the hole...  He removes some horsehair stuffing... He pulls out a small trinket, about six inches long... It MERMAID carved from ivory, with scrimshawed scales on her tail. A primitive but pretty effigy. Strange. YOUNG looks at it with a hungry curiosity... He rubs his thumb over her body... her breasts... He feels a bit guilty and puts her in his pocket. HOLD.
CLOSE ON: The hulking steam-powered foghorn engine. A pis pumps, gears grind, a huge flywheel spins and spins.

A SHOVEL FULL OF COAL enters frame and feeds the flames. Another shovel full. And another. THE FOG SIREN BLOWS EXCRUCIATINGLY LOUDLY. CLOSE, REVERSE: YOUNG shovels coal into the furnace, drip with sweat, wincing from the intense heat. He shovels again and again. THE FOG SIREN BLOWS: LOUD. CLOSE. PAINFUL. YOUNG BRACES HIMSELF, REELING FROM THE SOUND.

The contents of a kitchen cabinet are strewn about the fl OLD is inside the built-in cabinet up to his waist, butt If he had a tail, it’d wag. He’s looking for something. Something secret. YOUNG watches from afar in the staircase. OLD crawls out with a wooden crate. He grins with relief, pulling out a glass LIQUOR BOTTLE. He tremors a bit, it’s been too long

It’s dark. The two men sit in the cramped galley. A kerosene lamp flickers on the table between them, it is bent to one sid but still works fine. YOUNG looks at their meal, trying t hide his contempt: Lukewarm scrod and potatoes wait on battered mess plates. He rolls a cigarette on the table. coal-blackened hands stain the paper. OLD sets down two cups. Tin. Chipped china.

Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul. He pours a strange, thick liquid into the cups. Homemade hooch? He holds his up for a toast.
To four weeks. YOUNG pauses. Damn, it looks good. He could use a drink. he hesitates as if he thinks he is being tested. He decides to stay focused on the cigarette.
No, sir. Thank you.
Bad luck to leave a toast unfinished, lad. YOUNG tucks his cigarette behind his ear.
Meanin’ no disrespect, sir.
A man what don’t drink, best have his reasons.

Ain't it--  7. YOUNG stops himself to rephrase, more respectfully. It’s easy for him to be well-mannered. He takes his time, so a not to fumble with the multisyllabic words. I'd -- I had understood it’s ‘gainst regulations, sir.
Did you?
Yessir. OLD won’t budge. His cup is still raised.
From them’s manual.
Didn't picture you was a readin’ man.
Ain’t trying for trouble--

Then y’do as I say. That’s in yer book, too. Long pause. YOUNG smiles. His expression seems to say: “This old guy piece of work.” YOUNG takes his cup very deliberately. He stands up. Pause. He walks to the farmhouse sink and pours out the booze. He pumps some water into his cup. He sits back down. He holds up his cup to toast. He’s proud. He won.

To four weeks. OLD smiles -- a little too wide. They click cups. They drink...  8. Just as soon as they do: YOUNG RETCHES! A terrible taste. spits-up into his cup. A bit on the floor. OLD revels in the mishap.

Aye. The cistern needs a-lookin’ to. One of yer duties, lad. Or didn’t y’read yerself about it? Polishin’, swabbin’. Swabbin’ and polishin’. You’ll clean the brass and the clockwork, and you can tidy the quarters after. There’s well- more to be mended outside. YOUNG nods yes, his dry heaving subsiding.
D’y’hear me, lad?
Yessir--
(correcting him) “Aye, sir!”
Aye, sir. OLD starts eating his supper. Happy. His habits are a bit uncouth.
When the fog clears, you'll work through the dog watch--
Doggin’ it? Was ‘spectin’ I'd git up to the lantern.
I tend the light.
The rules is alternatin’ shifts-- OLD is startlingly stern. Unblinking. No tremors. A speck scrod hangs in his beard.
It’s the mid watch that’s to dread, lad: night to morning. My watch. (MORE )
Some new junior man I’m fixed with-- Y’act like y’never been to sea a’fore.
YOUNG hesitates, he hasn’t been at sea before -- clearly. not worth the trouble getting into it now.
Aye, sir. OLD looks at him with disgust.
That uni’form don’t fit ye.
Well, sir, it’s the one them establishment fellers gave me--
I’m meanin’ y’ain’t fit fer the wearin’ of it. See to yer duties. The light’s mine.
EXTREME WIDE SHOT: THE LIGHTHOUSE flashes. THE FOGHORN blasts.
YOUNG shovels more coal into the furnace. ANGRY! He casts a mean glance to the BOOK that rests on a chair the hot, whirring machinery: “Instructions to Light-Keepe July, 1881.” He curses the manual:
Son-of-a-bitch. THE FOGHORN BLASTS.

MUSIC CUE: Weird, haunting, ancient. THE CAMERA BOOMS UP THROUGH: The clinking and clanking ge of the light’s clockwork... A heavy lead weight on a chain slowly rises up through th center of the tower’s cast-iron spiral stairs... Wondrous patterns of swirling light move through the ironwork. The patterns shift rhythmically -- hypnotically. Otherworldly.

OLD sits in a sweat, mesmerized by the LIGHT. The machine whirs and clicks. THE HEAT from the huge THIRD-ORDER FRES LENS is immense. He is haloed in his pipe smoke. His jacket is off... Not cool enough. He opens his union suit...

Now he’s bare-chested. His alcoholic's gut protrudes from wiry frame. His strong, sinewy arms shine with sweat. The a faded three-masted ship tattooed on his chest, and seve crooked stick-and-pokes elsewhere -- all glistening. He pours grog into his tin cup. He toasts the light. Drin His eyes are heavy. He’s not drunk yet. But he wants to be. He pours another drink. Toasts.  11.
To ye, me beauty!

YOUNG is staring up at the magical light. Eight beams -- rotating starburst. Weird light patterns dance across the rocks below. It truly is a wonder. He yearns for it. It’s primal. He’s outside the signal shed. It’s an odd looking buildin with a huge protruding trumpet, held up by rickety struts YOUNG tries to light his cigarette. The wind and dampness the foggy air makes it impossible. His match won’t light. THE FOGHORN BLASTS. YOUNG strikes the match again. The match is lit... the wi blows it out. Damn! He strikes the match again... THE FOGHORN BLASTS.

YOUNG is finally smoking his cigarette. He slowly walks toward the shore... HE IS DRAWN TO THE LIGHT from the lighthouse reflecting o the water. He pauses, the waves lapping against the rocks. He starts walking into the tide... He walks further, he doesn't stop... HYPNOTIZED by the water... THE LIGHT...

head_text.subj: IS THAT A BALL OF LIGHT OUT IN THE SEA...

text: Further...  12. Further... Seaweed, moss, and slime surround his knees. Further... Then, slowly, A HUGE LOG, forty feet long and still sheat in bark, floats toward him... Another log... Another! He looks ahead and THE SEA IS FULL OF LOGS: A RIVER LOG DRIVE. He wants to run, but he can’t... he keeps wading deeper into the ocean of logs... He is almost up to his neck in water... Suddenly, he sees THE BODY OF A MAN floating face down in the logs:

head_text.subj: HE WEARS A WOOL MACKINAW COAT AND LEATHER CAULK BOOTS WIT

text: Nearby is some kind of tool floating: A WOODEN POLE WITH SINISTER IRON HOOK at the end of it (a peavey or “CANT HO for moving logs in a log drive). THE LOGS BEGIN TO JAM...
YOUNG wants to scream. He is almost totally submerged now

head_text.subj: WATER RISES ABOVE HIS MOUTH, HIS SCREAMS TURN TO SALT WAT

text: IMAGE, WIDE: Underwater, A MERMAID swims gracefully -- MENACINGLY -- in the sea toward CAMERA.
Water drips on YOUNG'S FACE Drip. Drip. Drip. He opens his eyes, startled. OLD is disrobing in the mirror, carefully -- he’s drunk.
Shingles.  13. YOUNG looks up. Water gets into his eye. OLD waddles to his bed, his pants around his ankles.
Tend to ‘em after the cistern. And the lamp, she needs oil. He flops down on the sagging mattress. Asleep instantly.
Aye, sir.
YOUNG lugs a heavy BAG OF CHALK up the incline of the isl It’s hard work. The wind blows like hell.

YOUNG, cigarette in his mouth, opens the hatch of a porri brick water tank: It lets out a putrid stench that knocks YOUNG'S face back a few inches. He tosses away the cigarette and covers his mouth and nos with the handkerchief around his neck. He looks inside: It’s full of mold and frothy sludge. It’s what he’s been drinking. He pours in the chalk. It slowly sinks. YOUNG drops in the mixing stick and swirls the water arou It looks sort of beautiful.

YOUNG scrapes at old cedar shakes. Scrape. Scrape. Scrape. He balances precariously on a rickety rung ladder. The wi blows hard, nearly knocking him off. It’s monotonous work takes it seriously, but with a chip on his shoulder. He looks up to the lighthouse: Curtains drawn in the lamp room.  14. He rips out several rotted shingles. The roof boards belo are ravaged with rot, too. Yep, here’s that leaky hole. He leans in...

head_text.subj: HE CAN SEE THROUGH A HOLE IN THE ROOF

text: OLD is asleep. But he’s moving... YOUNG leans in closer... OLD is softly HUMPING his sweaty mattress, just gently thrusting his hips. It’s subtle. A reflexive motion. YOUNG watches. Hold.
YOUNG opens a wooden door that almost falls off its hinge The shack is full. Barrels of dried fish, shelves of tool tapers, paper-wrapped parcels, wooden crates, casks, kegs rope...
YOUNG opens the door: COAL. Heaps of it. This door does fall off its hinges.
He loads up a wheelbarrow overfull with coal.
He pushes the wheelbarrow down the rock. (Needless to say the wheel squeaks.) He keeps pushing. One wrong step could cause the whole pi to tumble off of the wheelbarrow and down the island....

He makes his way to the door with the wheelbarrow... A SEAGULL stands in front of the old door, guarding it.  15. YOUNG flaps his hand, trying to scare it. THE GULL SQUAWKS. It turns its head, revealing: A MISSING EYE. The empty socket is gruesome and twisted. A war woun YOUNG is motionless, staring at the strange deformity... SUDDENLY, THE GULL YEOWS, LUNGING at him, clicking its be Instinctively, YOUNG HURLS a lump of coal at it... He misses... THE GULL mews this time, looks with its single eye, and f away. YOUNG watches the bird’s path... It flies past the lighthouse... The OLD man is looking down at him from the TOWER CATWALK exterior observation deck), puffing his pipe. Watching.

The double-doors of the breezeway open, revealing: Oil dr at the bottom of the staircase. THE OIL ROOM. YOUNG looks up... That is one tall staircase. The chains of the light’s clockwork weights look sinister they dangle down the center of the iron spiral steps and their shadows creep across the stone wall. They clink and clank, echoing ominously... YOUNG looks at the OIL DRUMS hiding beneath the stairs. T are much larger and more imposing than the heavy chalk ba
Clunk. YOUNG lugs an immense OIL DRUM up the steps.  16. Clunk.

Finally, YOUNG reaches the top of the stairs. The oil dru SLAMS down. His muscles tremor, sweat drips. He looks at the hatch to the LANTERN ROOM above... He is drawn to it... what’s in there? Slowly, he reaches toward the handle... He pushes... It’s closed. Stuck. Locked?
You don’t go in there! OLD startles YOUNG. Where did he come from? OLD emerges from the shadows: walk-drag, walk-drag, walk- drag.

Oil, sir. Says YOUNG, feeling somehow caught. He steps away from the drum, showing it to the old man, trying to hide an ounce of pride. He wipes the sweat from brow, panting. OLD limps around him, smoking his pipe. HE BLOWS SMOKE IN YOUNG’S FACE. YOUNG closes his eyes.
Tired?
No, sir. Says YOUNG, still panting. OLD throws a small, empty, THREE-GALLON BRASS OIL CANISTE him. YOUNG CATCHES it awkwardly.
Use this next time. Save you a helluva lotta trouble.
OLD continues to taunt him.
Catch yer breath, lad. Pause. I said catch your breath, lad! YOUNG grits his teeth.
Then bring that drum back down the ladderwell where y’found it. ‘Less yer fixin’ to burn the whole light down. 17. OLD climbs the ladder to the LANTERN ROOM. YOUNG watches spite.
Aye, sir. OLD pulls out a KEY RING attached to his watch chain. A h dozen BRASS KEYS in varying sizes.
Then see to the rest of yer duties. Yer behindhand already.
Aye, sir. YOUNG watches him unlock the door with the largest
Yer too slow. You a dullard?
No, sir.
Fooled me. OLD slams the door and locks it from the inside. HOLD on YOUNG. KEY.  18.
Scrod and potatoes again. YOUNG has his water. OLD pours himself a dram.

Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul. They drink. YOUNG winces a little. OLD is satisfied and starts eating.
(between chewing) Still tastes o’the head? YOUNG won’t nod yes. They eat in silence. OLD looks up at YOUNG... YOUNG ignores him.

Ah, find some chirk in ye, lad. Now is the time for gab and chatter. Y’best be enjoying it. Come a fortnight and the brace of us’‘1l be wantin’ to be ever silent as the tomb. Even to clap eyes on each other... It’ll make y’hotter than hell!
I ain’t much fer talkin’.
Reckon yer the first?
No, sir. I don’t.

Y’ain’t. Y’ain’t. Aye, the Chicopee, a fine-un, she were. Clean-built and trig-lookin’! None more fleet in ‘64 than she... We were on the breaks -- a mutiny it were. And why, ask ye? Why? What’s the terrible part of the sailor's life ask ye, lad? T’ain’t Cap’n, workin’ ‘em double-tide. Nay, no. (MORE )

‘Tis when the workin’ stops when yer twixt wind and water. Doldrums. Doldrums. Eviler than the Devil. Boredom makes men to villains... And the water goes quick, lad... vanished. And what’s the answer? What be the cure? The only med’cine is drink. Drink, lad! Keeps them sailors happy, keeps ‘em agreeable, keeps ‘em calm, keeps em--

Stupid. Pause. The two men stare at each other for a moment. OLD ERUPTS INTO A FIT OF LAUGHTER. He laughs so hard that runs through every conceivable sound. Is he drunk already YOUNG smiles in spite of himself, it’s hard not to. OLD pours another and toasts.
Curse me if there ain’t an old tar spirit somewheres in ye, lad. YOUNG starts to say something... but he stops himself. Pause.
Out with it, lad.
What... Why’d yer last keeper leave?
Him? My second? YOUNG nods yes, eating.
A damn fine sea farin’ man, he were. Pause.

Aye, went mad, he did. First a strangeness. A quietude. Then wild fancies struck him. Ravin’ ‘bout sirens, merfolk, bad omens and the like. In the end, no more sense left in him than a hen’s tooth. He believed there were some enchantment in the light.
He notioned St. Elmo did cast his very fire into it. Salvation, said he. YOUNG laughs.
Tall tales. He rolls a cigarette. OLD takes another drink. Slowly, his mood becomes somber.
I seen ye sparrin’ with a gull. YOUNG licks the paper.
Best y’leave ‘em be. Bad luck to kill a sea bird. YOUNG laughs, dismissively.

More tall tales? As YOUNG starts to put the cigarette to his lips... OLD G UP AND SLAPS HIM HARD IN THE FACE, out of nowhere! YOUNG stands in shock, knocking back his chair to the floor... He looks at OLD, stunned... YOUNG raises his fis defense... OLD IS ANGRY. DEAD SERIOUS.
Bad luck to kill a sea bird. Pause.  21. OLD breathes. He calms down a bit. He realizes how strang that was.
Pay me no mind, lad. None. Fix us up some coffee. Long night ahead. Drop o’coffee‘ll do us good. OLD doesn’t need to say he’s drunk.
Aye, sir. YOUNG looks again at OLD: He’s shaken. Terrified. A shell himself. More frightening than his outburst of anger was.

YOUNG lies in bed, smoking a cigarette. Reading the manua Can’t get comfortable. Restless. He holds the CARVED MERM in his hand, rubbing it reflexively in all the wrong plac The CLOCK ticks monotonously. Hold. OUT OF FOCUS IN THE BACK GROUND: A SEAGULL lands on the window. Pause. THE GULL starts tapping on the window. Tap. Tap. YOUNG hears it. Tap. Just as he turns to face it... THE SEAGULL has flown away YOUNG feels uneasy. He sits up. Back to his bed: the MERMAID CARVING is nestled in his sheets. Waiting for him.

YOUNG'S head moves up and down, shaking slightly. He is hiding in the shadows of the shed. The sound of rustling cloth and a clinking belt buckle are heard. CAMERA BOOMS DOWN...  22. He’s masturbating. CAMERA DOLLIES INTO: YOUNG’S head and into ... BLACK.

YOUNG emerges from the darkness of the shed, smoking. He closes the door behind him and leans against it. He sighs Soothed. Calm. The LIGHTHOUSE LIGHT illuminates YOUNG in waves of hot wh panels, otherwise, the soft glow of his cigarette indicat his location in the dark. Suddenly, he notices something odd, a DARK SPOT in the ce of the light. The panels of light streaking across him ha MAN'S SILHOUETTE within them. YOUNG looks up to the tower YOUNG'S POV: Is that OLD... hugging the lens? YOUNG is startled, confused. He looks again. YOUNG'S POV: Somehow, OLD is now on the CATWALK. Surveyin He pulls suspenders over his shoulders, as if getting dre after a night with a woman. A lantern in his other hand h him look below.... YOUNG skulks beneath the eaves of the roof, wary of the m above. He puts out his glowing cigarette... Hiding.
EXTREMELY WIDE SHOT: YOUNG pushes the wheelbarrow through storm, an oilcloth tarp over the coal. (Time has passed, shiner has healed.) He struggles through the mud... Hold.
You've been neglecting yer duties, lad!  23.
YOUNG is still, holding a rag against the brass he’s polishing.
OLD is fuming.
Don’t deny it.
Sir?
OLD stands in the galley, pointing at the floor in horror looks like it always does. How could it look any differen
What d’y’call this?
Sir?
What?
I mopped and swept. Twice over, sir.
Ye lyin’ dog.
I swept ‘em--
‘Tis begrimed and bedabbled.
Unwiped, unwarshed, and distained.
(under his breath) You git some kinda peart outta molestin’ me?  That sets 24.
Come now?
I already says--
How dare y’contree’dict me, y’dog-- YOUNG off:

Now look here, I ain't never intended to be no housewife nor slave in takin’ this job. It ain’t right! These lodgings is more ramshackle than any shanty boy’s camp I ever seen. The queen of England’s own fancy housekeeper couldn’t do no better than what I done, ‘cause I tell you, I scrubbed this here place twice over, sir and-

And I say y’did nothin’ o’the sort. I say, y’swab it again, and y’swab it proper-like this time, and then you'll be swabbin’ it ten times more after that. And if I tells ye to pull up and apart every floorboard and clapboard of this here house and scour ‘em down with yer bare, bleedin’ knuckles, you'll do it. If I tells ye to yank out every single nail from every moulderin’ nail-hole and suck off every spec of rust till all them nails sparkle like a sperm whale’s pecker, and then carpenter the whole light station back together from scrap -- and then -- do it all over again -- you'll do it! And by God and by Golly, you'll do it smilin’ lad, cause you'll like it, too. And you'll like it ‘cause I says you will! Contree’dict me again I dock yer wages. Y'hear me, lad?  25. Long, painful pause.
Aye, sir.
Now swab, dog. Swab! YOUNG does as he’s told - he grabs the mop and pail, fina resigned to his fate on this light station. OLD smiles.
Now that’s a good lad. That’s what I like to see. YOUNG starts to mop. OLD sings mockingly:
(singing) Oh what be the bane of a lightkeeper's life? What cause him to worry, to struggle and strife, What make him use cuss words, and beat at his wife? ‘Tis Brasswork.
OLD watches YOUNG polishing the brasswork.

(singing) What make him look ghastly, consumptive and thin? What rob him of health, of his vigor and vim? And cause him despair and drives him to sin.' ‘Tis Brasswork. YOUNG keeps polishing... harder... faster... harder...
YOUNG pushes the wheelbarrow through the storm (now in th other direction). It’s more difficult than before...  26.

(singing) The oil containers I polish until, My poor back is broken, aching; and still... He’s struggling... The wheelbarrow falls... Coal scatters all over the place. YOUNG stands still. He wants to scream.
YOUNG and OLD eat their scrod and potatoes in silence. RAIN AND WINDS BLAIR JUST OUTSIDE THEIR FLIMSY WALLS. Tension. Hold. Thunder claps. BLACK.

ANGLE ON: OLD is looking down from CATWALK of the tower, smokes his pipe. The sun shines behind him. CAMERA BOOMS DOWN TO: YOUNG, sitting on a KITCHEN CHAIR h up by ropes, attached to a jerky BLOCK AND TACKLE. One of wheels is coming off the pulley. YOUNG is whitewashing the tower, some 50 feet above the ground. A bucket of whitewash dangles on another rope.
Keep ‘em still, lad. YOUNG can’t. As usual, the wind blows wildly.
Aye, sir. His "paintbrush," a stick with a horsehair brush at the e shakes in his hands.
Whitewash must be even, lad. Bright! Shinin’! (MORE )
Like a silver whorehouse token. Give ‘em sailors a proper daymark. OLD lets the rope slip a bit. It truly scares YOUNG. Whitewash drips onto YOUNG’S face and clothes. He yells:
They're not going to see it ina Goddamn storm! OLD laughs.
They will after! And'1ll be glad to see it! Keep your temper now, lad. ‘Tis fine work. Yer makin’ high marks in me logbook. Them’s gospel! “Logbook?” thinks YOUNG. He stares at Old... for too long
I'll drop y’down a few feet. OLD lowers him some more; YOUNG slips quickly. Suddenly.. The pulley whirls too fast... YOUNG and the moving block shift quickly and SLAM to a halt.
Easy.
Never been in better hands. Another shift: HARD. Is OLD struggling? He anchors his good leg to the catwalk SHIFT! Further than the last one. THE WHITEWASH SPLASHES.
Easy! YOUNG thrashes in the wind...
Quit yer flailing, lad.
I ain’t!
Y'are!  28.
Keep still!
I am-- THE PULLEY’S BUSTED WHEEL FLIES OFF... the rope springs backward... YOUNG, the chair, and the block and tackle plunge to the ground! BLACK.

YOUNG comes to... He's covered in whitewash. How long was he out? He looks around... THE KITCHEN CHAIR shattered -- no more than kindling... OLD is nowhere to b seen... But THE SEAGULL with the missing eye is perched on his le It pecks him, scavenging the fresh meat.
Shoo. It pecks again. TAP. TAP. TAP. On his leg. The GULL blurt out a hostile kek
You! Git! It persists, pecking with its sharp beak. YOUNG is afraid of the bird. Afraid to harm it... TAP. TAP. TAP. Damn! It hurts!
THE GULL flies away, mocking him with mews and yeows  29.

OLD peers through tiny, delicate spectacles worn at a can The left temple tip is too high, and not looped round his ear. He is finishing writing an entry in his LOG BOOK. He writ the “period” with gusto. Pen down. Book closed. Glasses off. He rolls his desk top shut with a slam, and locks it with littlest KEY on his key chain. CAMERA pushes into the lock. REVERSE: YOUNG IS HIDING IN THE SHADOWS of the vestibule. WATCHING.

OLD sits on the same chair he’s been sitting in for the p weeks. YOUNG sits on an upturned NAIL KEG. YOUNG turns HARDTACK in his hand. He’s debating eating it KNOCKS it against the table. The biscuit clangs like meta Nope. YOUNG pours OLD a drink instead. Passes it to him.
Thankee, lad.
Winslow.
YOUNG musters a little courage.
Ephraim Winslow. These last two weeks, I'd... well, I’d like it, sir, if you’d call me by my name.
Listen to ye, giving orders, lad.
Winslow.  30.
Alright, alright... suits me just as fine, Ephraim Winslow. So, what brung such a one as you to this damnéd rock?
Such as what?
Pretty as a picture.
OLD laughs heartily.
Only joshing, lad, only josh--
Winslow.
Winslow -- What brings you to this rock, Ephraim Winslow? What were yer work afore?
Timber.
Timber...
Big timber. Up north. Canada ways.
Hudson Bay outfit?
The same.
True what they say? “Forest far as the eye can see.”
Yessir. Spruce, tamarack... white pine. “Bush,” them folk up there call it.
Had enough of trees, that it, then?  31.
Yessir.
Can’t say I blame ye. I hearn tell about that life. Hard goin’. Workin’ one man harder than two hosses, they say. No thankee. The sea, she’s the only situation wantin’ fer me.
Miss it?
Miss it? I ain’t never know’d anything but it.
Sailing.
Ah... Aye. Aye. OLD sees the sea life clearly in his eyes. The stories he must have.
Ain’t nothing what can touch it. He snaps himself out of it: Pause.

But can’t be draggin’ me old stump about... (Referring to his limp) Nay... not worth the trouble... now I’m a wickie and a wickie I is. I’m damn-well wedded to this here light, and she’s been a finer, truer, quieter wife than any a live- blooded woman.
Ever married?
Thirteen Christmases at sea... little ‘uns at home. She never forgave it. (MORE)
‘Tis fer the better. Pause. It’s clear that OLD has regrets. But rather than dwell on painful past, he changes the subject.

Since we're getting too friendly, Ephraim Winslow, tell me, what’s a timber man want with being a wickie? Not enough quiet for ye up north? Sawdust itching yer nethers? Foreman found ye too high-tempered for carrying an axe? That last comment rubs YOUNG the wrong way, but he tries to give in to the feeling.
Like you says, just had enough of trees, I guess. OLD looks him over suspiciously as he lights his pipe. YOUNG focuses on his cigarette. Lights. Draws.
Since I left Dad, well... I done every kind of work can pay a man. Some I ain’t near proud of.
Drifter, eh?
No sir! Just can’t find a post I can take a real shine to, so I keep movin’ along. And I ain’t the kind to look back at what’s behind him, see.
On the run? YOUNG gets defensive. Did he say too much?
No sir -- now look here, now -- I mean, nothin’ wrong with a man startin’ fresh, startin’ new, lookin’ to earn a living--
No...

...like any man, tryin’ to settle down quiet-like with some earnings... I read a man could earn six hundred and thirty -- I read one thousand dollars a year if he’s willing to tend a light far off shore... the further away, the more he earns. I read that, and hell, I says, yessir. Work. Save my earnings. Soon enough, I’1ll raise my own roof, somewheres up country, with no one to tell me “what for”... That’s all. YOUNG smiles. He thinks he is doing a pretty good job covering up his fear that OLD may sense more than he lets The cigarette helps.
Same ol’ borin’ story, eh?
You asked.
OLD sits in his rocker, knitting, smoking his pipe. YOUNG sits on the floor by the open stove, warming his ha He lights his cigarette with a splinter of kindling and closes the door. He takes a drag.
Say, why’s it bad luck to kill a gull? OLD puffs his pipe gravely.
In ‘em’s the souls o’ sailors what met their maker. YOUNG tries not to scoff again. OLD senses it.  34.
You a prayin’ man, Winslow?
Not as often as I might. But I’m God fearin’ -- if that’s what yer askin’. YOUNG tries to take another drag of his cigarette. He can It’s gone out... but he just lit it...
Russian Tar once told me: yer cigarette cinder goes out, there be someone somewhere’s a-thinkin’ bad thoughts of ye. YOUNG looks at OLD. OLD stops rocking.
They be a-cursing yer name. YOUNG re-lights the cigarette and takes a drag, not knowi what to make of that.
A toast to Ephraim Winslow, the God fearin’ man. Let ‘im settle down with none to tell ‘em “what for,” that his cinders always stay burnin’, and let fear never abandon ‘im. OLD toasts and drinks.
Amen. YOUNG feels uneasy.
- YOUNG sweeps the galley. - OLD ascends the tower stairs. He pauses, out of breath. - YOUNG is inside the fog trumpet, cleaning it. - OLD swiftly rolls his DESK closed and LOCKS IT.
- YOUNG winds the clockwork mechanism.  35. - YOUNG cleans the clockwork. Leaning in a strange positi his TOBACCO POUCH falls to the ground. - OLD goes into the LANTERN ROOM and LOCKS IT.

YOUNG is tossing and turning in bed. Restless. Hot. Sweat The sound of the waves crashing on shore is relentless. The CLOCK ticks monotonously. He tries to find a cool spot on the bed. He turns his pillow over... kicks off the linens like an angry toddler... He’s only in his underwear. The MERMAID carving is in bed his side. (Pinned on the wall behind him are clippings of desired objects from a Sears and Roebuck catalogue, a Tenderloin music hall program, and a few pornographic playing cards. Kicking off the linens doesn’t help. He sits up. He puts hand behind his ear... no cigarette. He goes to his shirt pocket hanging on the foot of the be rail... The TOBACCO POUCH isn’t there.
Shit.

MUSIC CUE: The eerie “light” music. YOUNG sees the POUCH resting on top of the spinning clockwork. He grabs it and quickly starts to head down stairs, but... Something stops him. A feeling. A question. The clockwork spins, the light hums on its brass track, t sea and wind sing their lilting song.  36. He looks up at the LIGHT swirling magically, undulating through the cast-iron lens deck. It is beautiful. Hypnoti THE LIGHT DRAWS HIM IN... But there’s something else... another noise... Whispering. Above. In the LANTERN ROOM. YOUNG tries to look through the iron grates of the lens d the bright LIGHT of the lamp makes it hard to see... he n to get closer... He grabs a chair from the shadows and stands on it. He listens. The whispering is more audible, though hard to define. He listens, trying to block out the white noise of the light It’s OLD all right, but YOUNG can only hear bits of whisp

(whispered) The light... seed... There’s another noise, now that his ear is more focused. It's a sticky, sweaty, slapping of flesh. Constant... It’s familiar... He puts his face closer to the iron and through glimpses the light and shadow above, he sees:

text: Is he...? JUST THEN, WHITE, VISCOUS FLUID DRIPS FROM THE GRATES... YOUNG QUICKLY AVOIDS IT IN DISGUST. HE LOOKS UP AGAIN... A HUGE, SLIMY, TRANSLUCENT SQUID’'S TENTACLE SLITHERS ACR THE IRONWORK... ...IT DISAPPEARS INTO THE DARKNESS.  37.
(louder) Veritas... YOUNG’s eyes widen.

YOUNG pumps water into a cup in the sink. He drinks. Pumps again. Drinks. Goes to pump again, but something stops him.. At the bottom of the cup is a dark film. He sweeps it up with a finger and looks: strange. Then, TAP, TAP, TAP on the window. He doesn’t seem to hea YOUNG pumps the water once again... it makes a rusty gurg sound... the water is more and more tainted, almost black Just then, he hears THE PLAINTIVE CRY OF A GULL, outside.

YOUNG exits the back door of the quarters. He looks out t the cistern. The CRY continues. He walks slowly toward the cistern. THE CISTERN'S HATCH IS OPEN. The CRY gets louder as he approaches. He looks in: DEAD GULLS float in the bloody cistern. ONE SEAGULL is tr to escape -- pathetically, desperately -- crying. Its win broken. JUST THEN, A LOUD FLUTTER OF WINGS IS HEARD ABOVE... and sound of a gull landing. YOUNG LOOKS UP...

HIS WINGS AND STANDS STRAIGHT UP, STRUTTING AGGRESSIVELY.

text: YOUNG is frozen. Then, THE GULL swoops his beak into the cistern... he gra the gull in his beak, and begins to eat it. YOUNG tries to intervene... ONE-EYE ATTACKS YOUNG’S FACE! YOUNG TEARS IT AWAY IN WILD RAGE...

IT AGAINST THE EDGE OF THE CISTERN...
OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER...
UNTIL IT IS A BLOODY PULP OF FEATHERS...

text: YOUNG breathes heavily. Guilty. Hold. The wind blows softly. He makes himself a cigarette, shaking. He looks sheepishl to the tower to see if OLD is watching. CAMERA BOOMS UP THE LIGHTHOUSE TOWER, past the catwalk, p the lamp, past the conical roof to... THE WEATHERVANE: THE ARROW POINTS WEST... Suddenly, the wind gusts... THE ARROW starts to jiggle a bit... The wind picks up... THE ARROW spins around, and around, around... It settles. Jiggling slightly in the wind, THE ARROW POIN HARD: EAST.
YOUNG stands in the open doorway of the bunkroom, wiping face with a handkerchief.
Cistern was open, sir and...  39. He sees OLD sobbing into his pillow and blankets. He’s as -- isn’t he? It's a strangely vulnerable sight. YOUNG doesn’t know what to do. Hold.

YOUNG'S face is reflected in the shining brasswork. His expression is still affected by the previous two scenes. spits on the brass and keeps polishing. OLD watches YOUNG work, writing in his logbook.
Wind’s changed.
Good riddance.

Don’t be so darn foolish. It’s the calm afore the storm, Winslow. She were a gentle westerly wind yer cursin’. Only feels roughly ‘cause you don’t know nothin’ bout nothin’ and there ain’t no trees on this here rock like your Hudson Bay bush. Nor’Easterly wind’1l come soon a-blowin’ like Gabriel's horn. Best board up them signal house winders.
Aye, sir.
‘Twill keep steady afore the tender comes in the morn, I ‘spect... but there’s dirty weather knockin’ about. YOUNG won't look OLD in the eye.
Somethin’ stirring in ye? Yer gettin’ off this island tomorry Winslow, don’t start grudgen me now.  40.
No, sir.
Keeping secrets, are ye?
No, sir. Pause. I could use a hand with them boards, is all.
YOUNG boards up the windows. OLD helps.
Now then, I’ve a surprise.
YOUNG stands precariously on a rock, pulling a ROPE that leads out into the water. OLD watches him.
Pull, pull, me good lad. Pull, Winslow! YOUNG pulls a wooden LOBSTER POT out of the water. YOUNG SMILES. So does OLD.
Look at ‘em! Better than fin fishin’!
Mutilated LOBSTER SHELLS are piled up on the plates. By t look on YOUNG & OLD’S faces, it was a satisfying meal. OLD pours two cups of his grog. Passes one to YOUNG.
‘Tis no crime to take a snort now. A clear night. (MORE )
And bein’ our last afore relief, I never know’d an inspector what wouldn't turn a blind eye, and I won’t take “no” for an answer. YOUNG gives in. He takes the cup.
Should pale death and treble dread make the... uh... Pause. He can’t remember the rest.
Ah hell -- to relief! They clink.
And how! They drink. YOUNG remembers how much he’s been missing the drink.
Damn! Like comin’ home. OLD pours another round. They drink. OLD pours another round. They drink.
YOUNG AND OLD are singing and pounding on the table.
(singing) Hurrah, we're homeward bound, Hurrah, we're homeward bound!
(singing) When we're arrived on Bedford docks Them bloomers all comin’round in flocks Them pretty girls, we hear 'em say "Here comes Jack with his nine- month pay"  42.
(singing) Hurrah, we're homeward bound, Hurrah, we're homeward bound!
They keep drinking. OLD smokes a cigarette. YOUNG smokes OLD’S pipe.

...and a pretty lass, she were, takin’ off her bonnet... but as I says, I'd broke me leg, and banged myself all up. It was to a nuns' hospital... All of them nuns were Catholics, I tell ye... They laugh.

Aye, but I never went to Salem since without hoping that I should see her, for beddin’ down wer’nt the same since. I don't know, but if I was a-goin’ to begin me life over again... well, womenfolk are apt to be dreadful ashamed of it, anyhow.
You feel shame when you lie with a woman?
I ain’t ‘shamed of nothing. Pause. They laugh.

Well, I’1l say it... I might even miss ye, Ephraim Winslow, yer fastly a true blue wickie in the making, you is. Thought one night you was bound to split me skull in twain, but yer a good-un. Why you'll be workin’ the lamp in no time -
Why haven't I?  43. Pause.
What?
The light?
I'm the keeper of this station, lad.
The... I ain’t... Some other station y’can tend the light.
The manual says--
My log is the only book on this rock--
I mean, I’m a wickie, you ‘Tis Gospel! says, but I ain’t trimmed one wick once--
I'm the keeper of the light, lad, I never let no man touch her--
I ain’t -- the book says we Don’t concern yerself with alternate-- the beacon! Mine, lad! OLD pours himself another drink. YOUNG laughs. The tension goes away.
Have it yer way... uh... Say, I never... I don’t know yer name.
Wake.
Yer Christian name?
Thomas.
YOUNG looks odd, troubled.
Thomas?
Thomas Wake, aye. YOUNG seems a little disturbed.
Call me Tom. OLD pours them another round.
To my friend Tom, and to gittin’ off this goddamned rock! They drink, spilling a bit of the liquor down their chins YOUNG snaps out of whatever seemed to be bothering him.

YOUNG stumbles around, undressing as he makes his way to bed. He leaves clothes here and there. He struggles to get his boots off. He can’t. Too drunk. He sits and breathes. He tries again. He gets one off. He tries the other... no use... He pulls harder, it comes loose, but the force is so great, YOUNG hits his head on lamp, mounted on the wall... He and the lamp crash to the floor. He passes out with hi pants around his ankles. His hair absorbs the kerosene of broken lamp.

YOUNG wakes up. He is so hung over. He wants to die. He needs water... The pitcher... the basin... both empty. He knocked them o  45. the night before. When did that happen? He looks down the staircase: OLD is asleep, sprawled out the steps. YOUNG goes to his chamber pot: it’s full of piss and shit He goes to Old's: piss and shit.
YOUNG wears his oilskins, smokes a cigarette, and carries full piss pots. THE WIND FIGHTS HIM. So does the hangover

head_text.subj: THE GALE HAS ARRIVED. IT'S STRONG. RELENTLESS. IT ALMOST

text: YOUNG stands over the cliffside. He tosses the contents of the CHAMBER POTS off the cliffs IT ALL SPLASHES BACK IN HIS FACE.
Fuck! He drops the chamber pots... they tumble to the rocks.
YOUNG hauls coal, his face covered in shit. It rains.
YOUNG stokes the fire. The siren is up and running.

YOUNG stumbles around the slippery rocks, pushing an empt wheelbarrow. Rain pissing on him. The hangover beating do upon his head. THE FOGHORN blasts relentlessly.  46. As he rounds a corner, he sees something WHITE in the bla rocks of the shore... He walks a few more paces... It is a BODY, lying still. Is it a dead sailor? He gasps... He drops the wheelbarrow and runs toward it! THE FOGHORN blasts. As he gets closer, it appears to be a WOMAN... A NUDE WOM washed up on the rocks. White legs and arms splayed out. He calls for Old, but he can’t hear him. He runs closer. THE FOGHORN blasts again. THE WOMAN appears to be DEAD, entangled in seaweed. YOUNG has to save her if he can. YOUNG goes to his knees... Wipes seaweed away from her face... SHE IS BEAUTIFUL. The most beautiful woman he has ever se The blood rushes to his head. His heart throbs. He looks over. He wants to touch her. He hesitates... but he does. He checks her pulse... Puts his head to her chest: Dead. Slowly, he touches her cheek, then her mouth... He moves his hand down her body, in the horror and grief her death, but also fascinated by her beauty, her perfect feminine shape... He makes his way past her breasts, to h ribs... Her ribs seem to have wounds -- deep slices. They aren’t bloody. They look almost like... GILLS. He moves his hand past her waist, toward her genitals, th he sees: SHE HAS A FISH’S TAIL! SHE IS A MERMAID!! He is frozen in terror. Then he looks back at her face... She opens her eyes and smiles at him.  47. She raises her arms, wanting his embrace... YOUNG opens his mouth to scream in horror... THE FOGHORN blasts! YOUNG runs away, fast as he can, flailing, stumbling over himself. He has almost no control over his body as he hur himself across the island, his screams drowned out by the FOGHORN.
YOUNG is out of breath from screaming. Wild eyed.
What’r y’splittin’ yer lungs fer?
Y’smell o’ shit. Best swab this mess afore the tender comes.
Y¥'do as yer told, lad! The quarters are dire.
Aye, sir.
THE GALLEY IS CLEAN. Well, as clean as it can be.
THE BUNKROOM is orderly. Mattresses rolled up. Everything in place. The CLOCK ticks monotonously.

OLD and YOUNG are in their topcoats, their gunny sacks ov their shoulders, their ditty boxes by their sides. They l out to sea, waiting for the tender.  48. It rains. The wind blows. Hold. The rain begins to pour.
YOUNG AND OLD sit at the table perfectly still. Drenched. A lit cigarette hangs on YOUNG’S bottom lip. The storm outside is something biblical. Very, very long pause.
They didn’t come. Long pause.
ANGLE ON: Huge waves crash.
ANGLE ON: Enormous waves crash.

Rain pours. A deluge. OLD is in his oilskins. He stands like a magician in fron the BOATHOUSE, facing the waves. He holds his right hand the sea with two fingers extended. He holds his bottle in other hand. He counts the waves as they crash onto the shore.
-..Four ...Five ...Six The waves are growing higher!
...Seven ...Eight ...Go down! He makes the sign of the cross (like a Catholic) on the n wave, and DOUSES THE SEA with liquor from his bottle.

OLD smiles at himself. I’ve still got it, he thinks. He t a swig from his bottle... Did he really make the wave descend? Or is it a coinciden Regardless, the wind comes back with a vengeance ... Behind him, the DORY that’s tied up wracks in the wind, beating against the sides of the boat house. The foghorn calls. The light flashes.

(singing “Blood Red Roses”) ‘Tis frost and snow and winter storm. (beat) Go down ye blood red roses, go down! (beat) And there’s many a ship lost round Cape Horn. (beat) Go down ye blood red roses, go down! (beat) Oh, ye pinks and posies... EIGHT... Go down! NINE! He makes the sign of the cross. Douses the sea. He stops singing and shouts:

head_text.subj: ABATE, O YE WAVES OF FATHER
GIFT, QUENCH THY SPLEEN, AND ABATE

text: He tosses some more liquor into the sea, and takes anothe swig himself.
(singing) Well, the captain he's o’er come with fear. Go down --

HE TRIES TO STAND, TO CATCH HIS BREATH...

text: ANGLE ON: THE BAROMETER. The needle is falling. It falls “RAIN” to “STORM.” YOUNG has his shirt off, shoveling coal. Sweaty. He has bits rags shoved in his ears, trying to muffle the sound. THE FOGHORN blasts. YOUNG catches his breath. He has one of OLD’S LIQUOR BOTT on his chair. He uncorks the bottle of liquor. Smells it. He thinks hard about drinking it. No. He corks it. He lights a cigarette instead. YOUNG turns... OLD is in the doorway soaking wet, and crazed. YOUNG wants to ask what happened, but decides it’s better to. YOUNG somehow feels too exposed without his shirt on.
(yelling over the noise) THE DAMP’S GOT TO THE PROVISIONS.
(yelling over the noise)
YOUNG pulls the scraps of fabric from his ears.
(yelling over the noise) THE DAMP’S GOT TO THE PROVISIONS!  51.
THE TWO walk through the storm.
OLD is shutting the door. YOUNG is shaking off the rain.
The damp’s got to the foodstuffs. The salt cod is out.
Out?
Blasted. Gone to rot.
Praised be.
Now will y’hear me?
Hear what?
That we best be rationing.
Rationing?
Insubordinate again--
It’s only been one day.
The Devil’s tail! YOUNG can’t figure out OLD’S train of thought.
Look, maybe the tender, maybe she did come. We missed her, is all. I can take the dory out--
Weeks, Winslow.  52.
What?
What d’ye mean, what?
Weeks? YOUNG is beginning to feel confused, afraid.
Weeks, aye. Weeks.
We slept in. Dead drunk.
It’s been weeks ago since we missed her, Winslow. And I’ve been askin’ ye to ration fer weeks now, too, and you've kept barking at me like a mad dog, sayin’ you can “take the dory out”--
Now look--
Don’t be losing yer head now.
This ain’t funny.
No, it ain’t. And I ain’t wantin’ to be stranded here with some damned lunatic.
Stranded?
That’s what I said.
I thought you said relief was comin’.
If we can wait out this storm.
The tender is comin’.  53. He says, trying to convince himself.
In ‘75 ‘Ol Striker were marooned here for seven long months, he was. The storm died on the mainland but here, waters were too rageful neither to launch nor land.
Yer just tryin’ to scare me. YOUNG is worried he is losing his mind. Or is it OLD who’ losing it?
Look at ye. Pretendin’. But ye well- know yer lot.
The storm continues. OLD holds two SHOVELS. He throws the shorter one at YOUNG.
OLD starts digging like a madman in the wind and rain.
YOUNG joins, afraid of what they might be digging up.
THEY have dug a deep, muddy hole. About the size of a GRA
OLD unearths... A WOODEN CRATE. He gives it to YOUNG.
They open it...  54. INSIDE ARE TEN FULL BOTTLES OF BOOZE.
(to himself, ironic) Rations.

THE TWO DRINK while they ration out supplies. OLD is marshalling YOUNG. They are pretty drunk already. YOUNG EYES A LEDGER written in the LOGBOOK, marked with pounds of coal, number of tins, gallons of oil, etc. OUTSIDE, THE RAIN HAMMERS DOWN. WIND HOWLS.

... their gums grew swollen, the color of bone, then to rot. Tarry blood oozed, teeth droppin’ to deck with none to hold on to. OLD proudly shows off his missing front teeth. Their legs withered and turned gangree’nous, every shade of the peacock’s tail. The worst of us couldn't fend ‘gainst the ship rats what gnawed at the soles of our feet. “Land ho!” hears I, but only grass and trees on that island. So we drunk upon the sap, and et upon the grass. ‘Twas providence saved us from turnin’ to each other’s flesh, like bare-naked savages. And ‘twas that scurvy what left me locked ever since. Thought you said you broke it.
Eh?

Fallin’. Fallin’.

But they never listened... they’d never... if I had the chance, they’d never -- none of them Goddamned lily-livered Canadian bastards. Lack-gall cowards. The eaves be fallin’ fast.

Yep. Them eaves is gonners.  OLD turns. Pause. 56.
Give me yer cant hook, I says to him, but foreman Winslow that goddamned Canady son-of-a-bitch fool bastard... always callin’ me a dog. A filthy dog.
Winslow?
Yeah, that bastard. “I’1ll show you who’s a dog.”
Winslow?

He’s always raggin’ on me, like you. Damn fool nonsense.
Raggin'?

Yeah, that’s the trouble with Winslow.

The trouble with you is eatin’ grass without no teeth.
Come now?
Yer sea maties’ teeth was fallen out--

Oblige me.
Ye rip it out and ye swallow it.
You rip it out and you swallow it.

I don’t know ‘bout that.
Y'don’t?
I don’t.

What?

That’s what I mean.

That’s the trouble with ye!

(Suddenly) I want a steak! I want a goddamned
Shut it.
A steak! A steak! A rare, bloody steak. If I had a steak, I could, oh boy, I could fuck it.
You don’t like my cookin’?
Don’t be such an old bitch.
You’re drunk, you don’t know what yer talkin’--

How could I possibly like the horseshit you fix us for supper?  60. YOUNG (CONT’D) OLD Them tin kitchen shanty cooks Yer drunk, or ye wouldn’t b gave us fried donuts three saying that! Yer drunk! Yer times a day and country ham drunk! Yer drunk! bigger than yer fist.
I’m drunk? I’m drunk?
Ye heard me.
You’ve been drunk since...
Damn ye.
Drunk since I first laid eyes on you.
Yer fond of me lobster, ain’t ye?
Yer drunker than a Virginy fence.
I seen it, yer fond of me lobster.
Say it.
Say it.
OLD is furious.
Damn ye!
I don’t have to say nothin--  61.

Let Neptune strike ye dead, Winslow! OLD becomes dreadfully serious. YOUNG is afraid. Silent. OLD speaks more powerfully and passionately than any Tamburlaine or Lear. He calls out to the gods of the sea Man possessed:

Hark, Triton, Hark! Bellow, and bid our father, the sea king, rise up from the depths, full- foul in his fury, black waves teeming with salt-foam, to smother this young mouth with pungent slime... (to Young) «+. to choke ye, engorging yer organs till ye turn blue and bloated with bilge and brine and can scream no more... only when, he, crowned in cockle shells with slithering tentacled tail and steaming beard, takes up his fell, be-finnéd arm -- his coral-tined trident screeches banshee-like in the tempest and runs you through the gullet, bursting ye, a bulging bladder no more, but a blasted bloody film now -- a nothing for the Harpies and the souls of dead sailors to peck and claw and feed upon, only to be lapped up and swallowed by the infinite waters of the dread emperor himself, forgotten to any man, to any time, forgotten to any god or devil, forgotten even to the sea... for any stuff or part of Winslow, even any scantling of your soul, is Winslow no more, but is now itself the sea. OLD is shaking like a lunatic. Veins popping in every direction. Exhausted... eyes drilling into YOUNG. YOUNG sweats. What can he do? What can he say? Has he bee cursed? Doomed?  62.
Alright. Have it your way. I like yer cooking.
The cataclysmic storm continues. Flash. The wind. Flash. The rain. Flash. The waves. Flash. The foghorn. Flash.
CAMERA PUSHES IN ON: YOUNG watching the light through the lens deck. Hypnotized.

WHISPERING ABOVE. Or is it just the spinning lens? The sound is familiar and alien. Male and female. Celesti He pulls out THE DINNER KNIFE and holds it to the light.. He smiles like a Jack-o'-lantern. Hold.
YOUNG unlaces his boots and puts them in his pockets, hee up. He creeps toward the TOWER like a stocking-footed burglar.  63.

YOUNG slinks up the stairs. INT. MACHINE ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER YOUNG is trying to pick the LOCK of the LANTERN ROOM with DINNER KNIFE. HE is twisting and turning the KNIFE roughly in the lock. Twisting... Jiggling... SUDDENLY, the knife blade breaks in two...
(under his breath) Son-of-a-bitch. He looks at the KNIFE. It’s now very thin. Needle-like. A idea!

YOUNG tiptoes to Old’s DESK with THE THIN, BROKEN DINNER KNIFE... He can hear OLD snoring (0.S.) upstairs. He brings it to THE LOCK... He jiggles the knife... the top jiggles too... It’s unlocked already! He quietly opens the desk... THE LOG BOOK is gone. Son-of-a-bitch. OLD keeps snoring (0.S.).

YOUNG watches OLD sleep. THE LOGBOOK and spectacles rise fall on his belly. His loud SNORE follows. THE BRASS KEYS hang on their chain, his watch tucked under his pillow.  64. WATER DRIPS from the ceiling, plinking into a pail. YOUNG creeps forward toward OLD, trying not to make any noise. The sounds of THE STORM outside help to disguise s of his movements. And the plink... plink... plink... OLD keeps snoring... Every step is silent... Plink... plink... plink... He reaches his hand out, unfurling like a lure in slow- motion, fishing for... the BRASS KEYS... YOUNG sees OLD’S sweaty THROAT... Pause. YOUNG slowly brings the KNIFE out... Another step forward... The floorboards betray YOUNG with a loud GROAN. YOUNG stops. Caught! He quickly throws his knife hand beh his back. OLD opens one eye.
Queer way to wear yer shoes.
Didn’t wanna wake you, is all. Pause. Long night. Pause. And such.
Mm-hm. The sun is over the yardarm. Best find me some winks afore the day draws farther on. OLD FARTS. Pause. YOUNG stands still.  65.
Get to yer duties or I'll give you a real keelhauling. Pause. YOUNG stands still, thinking.
You ain’t even human no more. Workin’ apart from folks so long. What’d you lose? Pause.
Yer only tol’rable when yer dunk.
Get to work, says I! YOUNG STANDS STILL, DEFIANTLY. CAMERA REVEALS: THE KNIFE STILL HIDDEN IN YOUNG’S HAND.
To work! Pause. OLD FARTS. YOUNG SMILES AGAIN, A WEIRD, FALSE SMILE.

YOUNG wears his OILSKINS, pushing the wheelbarrow through tempest. It’s almost impossible. Is he drunk or hung-over HE MUTTERS TO HIMSELF. He has a BOTTLE in the barrow, floating in rain water. Th it. No coal. YOUNG keeps his eye on the bottle. Watching Caring for it.
The fog machine whirls, pumps and... BELLOWS! YOUNG shovels a heap of coal into the furnace. Shirt off. OILSKIN HAT on.  66. He takes a swig from the bottle. THE FIRE ROARS. ANOTHER BIG, LONG SWIG.

head_text.subj: THE GALE IS MERCILESS AS EVER.

text: YOUNG is pulling up THE ROPE OF A LOBSTER POT... IMAGE: THE MERMAID’S BREAST. IMAGE: HER MOUTH. YOUNG pulling the rope... IMAGE: THE LIGHTHOUSE, at a 45 degree angle, LOOKING LIKE PENIS. YOUNG pulling the rope... IMAGE: THE MERMAID’S SLIMY VAGINA. IMAGE: YOUNG’S HANDS TIGHTLY GRIP A CANT HOOK.
IMAGE: THE MERMAID’S FACE, UPSIDE DOWN. SCREAMING, MOANIN EYES ROLLED INTO THE BACK OF HER HEAD. YOUNG pulling... IMAGE: CLOSE ON: THE BACK OF A MAN’S HEAD. WOOL MACKINAW COLLAR.

head_text.subj: YOUNG IS MASTURBATING IN THE DARK. FURIOUS. ANGRY. CONFUS

text: Shirt off. Oilskin hat on. Shivering. Rain pisses down through the holes in the roof. He is holding the MERMAID CARVING. Staring at it. It’s no working. He throws his head back, thinking of someone, something. does it with a fury... lust...  67. It’s taking too long to get anywhere. Back to the MERMAID CARVING... Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. His hand is getting tired. Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. He can feel something coming, it’s rising within him, he his other hand on the rickety wall... it’s coming... soon He’s lost it. IMAGE: WIDE: YOUNG is straddling the MERMAID (the real on not the carving), his pants half down, FUCKING HER WHILE SEA LAPS OVER THEM.

IMAGE: THE MERMAID’S HANDS GRAB YOUNG'S THROAT, DRAGGING INTO THE SEA AND SLIME. IMAGE: A MAN’S FACE (not Young’s), SURROUNDED BY A MACKIN COLLAR, GURGLES, SCREAMING, SUBMERGED IN WATER. BACK TO THE SHED: YOUNG howls, an animal in an iron trap! HE THROWS THE MERMAID CARVING...

Desire quickly turns to shame. The foghorn calls. The wind howls. Rain pours into the sh YOUNG looks at the broken MERMAID and curls into a ball o the wet ground with his pants around his hips... He seems like he is about to cry... But he laughs. He laughs as if a great weight has been lifted.

I fixed you. You bastard. You can’t git to me. I’1l get yer gullet! He crawls to the broken carving and starts wildly stabbin with the DINNER KNIFE! IMAGE: YOUNG is pulling the rope down by the rocks... HE PULLS UP THE LOBSTER POT...  68. BACK IN THE SHED: YOUNG, SEIZED WITH FRIGHT.

head_text.subj: A SEAGULL FLIES RIGHT BY YOUNG, SQUAWKING AS IT GOES
YOUNG ALMOST FALLS IN THE WATER FROM TERROR.
SMALL CRABS CRAWL OUT OF THE EMPTY EYE SOCKET.

text: YOUNG AND OLD are singing, dancing, do-si-do-ing, swingin each other with linked elbows around the room in circles.
(singing) She swung her hips, she winked her eyes, that sassy little whore, So I took her in, I gave her gin, and danced her on the floor!
(singing) Doodle let me go, me girls, doodle let me go, Hurrah, me yaller girls, doodle let me go!

(singing) Oh ‘round and ‘round the sofa, boys, wasn't it a show She grabbed hold of my bobstay and she wouldn't let it go! They laugh, and break away from each other... OLD begins diddling “Ten Penny Bit” and dancing a jig. (Diddling is a kind of maritime scat-singing that mimics fiddle) YOUNG claps while OLD dances. His dancing is pretty impressive, especially with his bad leg. How’s it possibl YOUNG joins the diddling and jigging... OLD begins clapping, too. He claps a little faster, YOUNG matches his tempo.  69. IT’S COMPETITIVE. FIERCE. MEAN. They diddle, jig, and clap faster and faster and faster a faster...
Dance! Dance, Winslow! Dance!

(singing, very, very, very fast) Come all you boys who wish to hear How we got up to the woods last year, Oh, into the sleigh we jacked our boots Our teamster pointed to the big blue spruce Timmy-ran-tin-ah Falla-doo-a-dah Rant-and-roar and drunk-on-the-way! Timmy-ran-tin-ah Falla-doo-a-dah-- LIGHTNING FLASHES THROUGH THE WINDOW.

YOUNG AND OLD are slow dancing. Arms around each others’ shoulders. Tired. YOUNG looks at him with anger and suspicion. OLD sings a ballad. His voice isn’t exactly pretty, or al on key, but the ballad is beautiful, with a haunting melo and his performance is moving. He’s deep into it, experiencing every moment.

(singing) Oh, where have all the evenings gone? Oh, where is the ale and whisky I’ve tasted? Gone the same way as the pay I done wasted, On a Monday morning. If but the birds were gin, If but the sun was a hearty reveler, If I might give someone else me liver, On a Monday morning. (MORE)

My lover she lies asleep, My lover is warm, and her heart is mellow, I would give the whole world just to share her pillow, THE SONG has changed YOUNG’S mood, he has softened... Timidly and quietly, he joins the last line...

(half-singing) On a Monday morning. Thunder rumbles... They lean into each other... It is very tense... It seems like they might kiss... No, that’s madness. Pause. YOUNG pushes OLD away. He puts up his fists like an old-t boxer. OLD does, too. They take turns hitting each other, play fighting. OLD ke hitting YOUNG, as YOUNG is more drunk.

You bastard. THE PLAY-FIGHTING ESCALATES... THE PUNCHES GROW HARDER... THEN... YOUNG grabs OLD and hurls him against the moldy cabinet! cackles. THEY send the whole cabinet of cups and dishes clattering down. OLD throws plates at YOUNG, almost hitting him... dinnerw smashing on the walls. They start throwing the scraps of fish bones and potato s from their plates at each other... laughing. They're hysterically drunk. Demented. YOUNG throws the soapbox... It breaks apart against the  71. range! They get closer to each other, running out of things to throw. Howling laughing...
OLD pulls out another bottle and slams it down in front o YOUNG.
Drink.
Aye, aye, sir.
In one draft.
You do it.
GODDAMN YER CALUMNY! The law says ye do as I command! Any word but “aye” be mutiny! Pause. YOUNG pulls the cork off. He drinks, and drinks, liquor pouring down the sides of his stubbly face.
Atta boy!!
Aye, aye, AYE, AYE! AYE!
BOTH of them pour booze all over their faces. THUNDER CLAPS. LIGHTING FLASHES THROUGH THE WINDOW.
YOUNG is so drunk, it’s hard to believe. He is soaked in liquor. OLD has his head on YOUNG'S shoulder. He falls in and out consciousness.  Pause. Pause. 72.
Thomas.
Aye?
It’s Thomas.
Aye.
No, I... I’m Thomas.
I'm Thomas. You’re Ephraim.
I lied.
Well, I‘1ll be scuppered.
I’m Thomas. Tommy.
Tommy ? (laughs) Tommy Winslow.
Tom Howard.
What’s Winslow?
Nothing.
Nothing?
It ain’t my fault... I...
Can I trust you? OLD sits up. Thunder rumbles.
Don’t be spilling any of yer beans to me.
No... It wasn’t that way, is all...
I ain’t interested.
So I can trust you?
Never did like being confided to.
I know what you’re fixin’ to do. Git me all liquored up--
Yer guilty conscience is ever as tiresome-borin’ as any a guilty conscience.
It was a drive, see...
Worse.
A log drive and... he’s raggin’ on me. No -- I see what yer doing...
Nothing.
Look, I mean, look, Tom... don’t be working to twist words out of my head.  74.
I ain't.
look... I can’t, I can’t.
Shut up yer own rag box.
I can trust you.
No.
I trust you, Tom.
Y’trust me?
No. I don’t trust you at all. They laugh. They drink.
The CLOCK ticks monotonously. Somehow, the sounds of the storm have diminished. The plinking slowly disappears, to CLOSE ON: YOUNG looking feral-eyed. Utterly still.

And I had ‘im handy and helpless. Alone. Too far downstream. And I wanted to do ‘im in. I admit I did. Seein’ the back of his head. One swipe of the cant hook’d be all. It was... I didn’t... but I didn’t... I did not. The day was long as hell on that drive. I was lead-tired. I admit it. But I saw him slippin’, not me. And we saw the jam comin’. And I stood and he slipped. He shouted up. And I just stood. “Tom, you dog!” And I stood, is all. Just stood and watched ‘im git swallowed down by them logs. (MORE )

All I thought when he was done is, “I could use me a smoke.” That’s it. So, I packed up his kit and fixins, as if they was mine. And, well, Ephraim Winslow has a spiffy clean slate. Thomas Howard, he don’t. No prospects. How else am I gonna find respectable work? Pause. YOUNG turns. OLD is gone... Did he even hear this?
Tom? Long pause.
Tom?!
(far away, whispered, echoing) Why’d y’spill yer beans, Tommy?
OLD’S voice echoes.
The chains clink, echoing too...
(whispered) Why’d y’spill yer beans? YOUNG ascends the stairs...
THE DOOR to the CATWALK FLIES open... Rain blows wildly into the machine room. YOUNG goes through the door...  76.

head_text.subj: THE WIND AND RAIN ARE VICIOUS ON THE WALKWAY ATOP THE TOW

text: They push and slap YOUNG as he carefully makes his way to A BODY. It’s face down. Is it the OLD man? NO. But it’s familiar - the MACKINAW COAT... THE HIGH LEATHER BOOTS WITH THICK HOBNAILED SOLES... For some reason, known least to YOUNG, he reaches out for familiar man and turns the wet body over: IT'S YOUNG! HIS DOPPELGANGER. PALE. DEAD.

head_text.subj: THE HULKING FOOTSTEPS ARE LOUD. VIOLENT. RIGHT BEHIND YOU
IT SPINS YOUNG AROUND... IT'S OLD. NAKED.
HE HAS YOUNG WITHIN HIS POWER. HIS WILL. BUT... THE OLD M

text: YOUNG tries to get away. But he can't. The OLD man is too strong. And something starts to happen. Something horribl THE OLD MAN SLOWLY OPENS HIS EYES. YOUNG's expression tells it all: fascination moves quickl through confusion and deep, unknown terror as ...

head_text.subj: A LIGHT BRIGHTER THAN ANYTHING BATHES YOUNG'S FACE

text: OLD'S EYES SHINE LIKE THE LIGHTHOUSE BEACON INTO YOUNG’S FACE.

YOUNG tries with utter desperation to launch the DORY out sea. He throws on a CORK LIFE VEST. HUGE WAVES CRASH AGAINST HIM.  77. It is a bitter struggle as he drags the DORY along the runners... YOUNG throws the OARS in the boat... Suddenly...

head_text.subj: OLD SWIPES THROUGH THE AIR WITH A FIRE AXE, SMASHING THE

text: OLD chases YOUNG across the island, wielding the axe... YOUNG runs into the QUARTERS.
OLD bursts in and swings the AXE at YOUNG, missing... OLD buries THE AXE deep in the kitchen table. He falls wi exhaustion. They are both soaking wet.
You crazy son-of-a-bitch! You smashed up the life boat!
Yer abandoning yer post! YOUNG storms into the...
WATER is leaking from the ceiling, heavily. It flows down of the walls.
What’re you gonna do? Send for the lighthouse establishment?
Certain, says I! I’1l report ye, I‘ll bring the inspector up--  78.
I’ll report you. I know what you done...
Who’s reportin’ who? Ephraim Winslow? Or Thomas Howard? I know what you done--
(suddenly) You killed yer second. YOUNG SMILES.
For once, OLD is speechless. In horror. YOUNG is happy as can be. Crazed. Manic.

I found him. Yer one-eyed junior man. In the lobster pot. He went mad? You made him mad with that charm! That scrimshaw trinket, it’s a sea spell to keep him from yer secret... But I broke it, see. I’m free. YOUNG rummages awkwardly through his pockets and finds th broken pieces of the IVORY MERMAID. He throws it to OLD’S feet! Young smiles in triumph and does a celebratory jig!
Free from yer designs! OLD makes no expression. YOUNG stops jigging.
And I got it all figgerd out, ‘cept what’s the secret mischief yer keepin’...  79. He points to THE LANTERN ROOM. .-. up there!
I figgerd you, old timer. This whole time, I’ve been watchin’ you and I’ve got you figgerd. OLD looks at YOUNG with pity.

Jesus, Mary and Joseph, Tommy. Last night you made a confession ‘twould make a saint swear. I don’t have nothin’ to confess, but you, Tommy, a-spillin’ yer beans... now look what it’s done to ye. It’s made ye mad. I knew ye was mad when y’smashed up the life boat just now, a-chasing me with an axe, tryin’ to kill ‘Ol Tom. Don't y’trust me, Tommy?
Better hand me the dinner knife you pocketed. Y’aint safe with it.
Them’s government property. YOUNG does so, looking like a guilty child.
There’s a good lad. OLD, stepping on it, breaks it in two and throws it in th stove.
Deducted from yer pay.  80.
Look at yer shiverin’. Yer so mad, y'know not up from down. How long have we been on this rock? Five week? Two days? Where are we? Help me to recollect, who are you again, Tommy ?

I’m probably a fig’ment of your ‘magination. This rock is a fig’ment of yer ‘magination, too. Yer probably wand’rin’ through a grove of tag alders, up in north Canady, like a frostbitten maniac a- talkin’ to yerself, knee-deep in the snow, the blizzard overtakin’ ye. Pause.
I could use a smoke.
We're outta drink. They smile at each other like old friends.

HONEY DRIBBLES into a BRASS KEROSENE CANISTER. YOUNG still wears the cork vest as he drips the HONEY, smoking his cigarette. OLD watches with intense curiosity. YOUNG TAKES OUT A TIN OF TURPENTINE. He pours it into the CANISTER, too. He begins to stir it with a scrap of rebar
Thieves’ oil. YOUNG smells it. He likes it. He pours OLD a cup.  81. OLD drinks.
Oooooh, monkey pump! They both drink... fighting over it like giddy children.
ANGLE ON: THE BAROMETER. The needle is falling. It falls “storm” to a blank space below. Off the chart, so to spea
Will it survive?
YOUNG and OLD laugh and laugh and laugh, holding cups of thieves’ oil. YOUNG still wears the life vest. WATER DRIP

THE AXE in the table top between them. They keep laughing in a frighteningly hysterical manner.. Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... SUDDENLY, THE FORCE OF A WAVE CRASHES THROUGH A WINDOW... WATER FLOODS INTO THE ROOM WITH RAPID SPEED. But YOUNG & don’t notice. They keep laughing... Laughing...  82. Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... HOLD. BLACK.

THE KITCHEN is an absolute catastrophe. However terrible looked the night before, it is even worse now. Mess is everywhere and every surface is soaking wet. Water drips way that suggests the storm is over. The quarters utterly destroyed, and by the looks of it, not just by the storm. THE AXE still stays buried in the table. YOUNG is sitting in the SINK, drinking TURPENTINE straigh from the tin. He’s in his undershirt and trousers, but st wearing the life vest.
This place is a sty.
Mornin’ to you, too.
I wish I could go fer a walk.
Be my guest. You’ll get drowned.

The CLOCK ticks monotonously. The room is half flooded. YOUNG stands in ankle deep wate pissing, missing the chamber pot, following it around as floats across the room. As he does this, he is taking off life vest... Suddenly, he begin to retch... he throws up. He falls to his knees... splash... and sees... OLD’S LOGBOOK... it floats by... OPEN.  83. YOUNG fumbles around to snatch it up, to bring it to the window light. He begins to leaf through the pages... There are beautiful mementos of Old’s past, newspaper clippings, tintypes... YOUNG finds locks of Old’s children’s hair... he touches gently... Then... HE FINDS THE LOG ENTRIES... (CAMERA doesn’t see the entri YOUNG almost slams it shut. But he doesn’t. He keeps reading... YOUNG'S face drops. The CLOCK’S ticking seems to grow lou every second. YOUNG looks like a ghost. HE SMASHES THE CLOCK WITH HIS FIST. No more ticking. Glass and blood.
OLD sits in a heap of trash. He’s wearing only his sweaty baggy, mostly unbuttoned union suit, his vest with his wa chain, and his cap. He smokes his PIPE... It goes out.
Damn. He tries to find a match in the chaos.

(to himself) Fiery pit! Ain’t there no justice left in this world? He roots through the rubbish, throwing it around... Suddenly, the sound of a MATCH striking (0.S.)! OLD turns around, startled.  84. YOUNG is right behind OLD... with a LIT MATCH... utterly still. Eerily still. He calmly lights OLD’S PIPE. OLD feels a bit uneasy.
Thankee. Pause.
What’s wrong with yer hand? YOUNG looks at the match hand in confusion.
T’other one. YOUNG looks: his left hand leaves blood marks on the tabl He slithers his cut hand away.
Ye hear o’ tetanus?
Tet-a-nus? (quietly, rigid) Yep.
It started as a sliver of a cut is all... YOUNG is motionless. Boiling.
I said I heard of it.
... from the forestaysail when we shoved off...
Can’t you never shut up.
«+. but come a fortnight...  85.
Stop.
The bosun was a-shakin’...
Shut up, I says.
... his chops was locked tighter than an anchor bend-- YOUNG explodes:
SHUT IT! I told you I can’t hear no more! Hold yer jaw!
What were it yer accused me of? Y’already told me y’had me figgerd--
I’m tired out of listening to your damned-fool yarns and your Cap’n Ahab horseshit -- you sound like a goddamned parody. Givin’ and nagging orders like a spinster schoolmarm... and... and...
(to himself) all-the-while turning this ‘Nother conniption fit. station to the Devil’s own (to Young) rum hole. Yer makin’ a fool of yerelf.
Well, it’s all horseshit, yer leg, and yer sea life, all of it. And I’m tired of it. If I hear one more word of horseshit coming from your foul, rotten tooth, smelly old mouth--
Ye--
Shut up yer gum, Goddamn it -- I ain’t finished. (MORE )

I'm sick of lookin’ at you, I’m sick of lookin’ at week-old food in yer beard starin’ me in the face like it ‘spects me of somethin’. You think yer so damned high and mighty cause yer a goddamned lighthouse keeper? Well, you ain’t a captain of no ship and you never was, you ain’t no general, no copper, you ain’t the president, and you ain’t my father -- and I’m sick of you actin’ like you is! I’m sick of yer orders! I’m sick of your laughing, your snoring, and your goddamned farts. Your damned goddamned farts. Goddamn yer farts! You smell like piss, you smell like jism, like rotten dick, like curdled foreskin, like hot onions fucked a farmyard shit-house. And I'm sick of yer smell. I’m sick of it! I’m sick of it, you goddamned drunk. You goddamned, no-account, drunken, son-of-a-bitch-bastard- liar! That’s what you are, you're a goddamned drunken horse-shitting -- short -- shit liar. A liar!
Long pause.
Y’have a way with words, Tommy.
Damn you.
Yer relieved of yer duties.
No need to tell me, old timer. YOUNG reveals the LOG book. He reads aloud:
Assistant slept late. Work below standard. Turns the page.
Attitude Hostile  87. Turns several pages.
Assistant missing. Given to habitual ‘self-abuse’ in the supply shed. A few more pages.
Drunk on duty. Turns a page.
Incoherent speech. Another page.
Attempted to abandon his post. Assault. Theft. Another page.
I do not feel safe with him. Recommend severance without pay.
YOUNG throws THE LOGBOOK at him.
Yer trying to ruin me?! I’m a hard worker! I am! I work as hard as any man!
Ye lie, Thomas.
Stop it. Y’lie to yerself, but y’ain’t have the sauce to see it. YOUNG changes his tune:  88.
Work as hard as a man and two horses, you said so yerself, I work like I’m a damn foreigner. YOUNG works at getting into the BREEZEWAY toward the TOWE OLD stands in his way. YOUNG begs, desperately:

Please, please, let me into the light, old man, and I’11 show you what I can do for -- I can -- I can do better -- I can. I’ve learned so much from you. Another chance. Let me show you. Forgive and forgit, I says -- just let me into that lantern, is all, don’t make me beg-- I will -- I’1l beg if that’s what you want, PLEASE-- OLD keeps his ground.
Stand down.
SELFISH BASTARD! Keepin’ it all to yerself. Left yer old lady, yer children for what? For what?! OLD smiles. Creepily.

Look at ye, handsome lad, with eyes bright as a lady. Come to this rock playin’ the tough, ye make me laugh with yer false grum. Ye pretended to some mystery in yer quietudes, but there ain’t no mystery, yer an open book. A picture, says I. A painted actress screaming in the footlights, a bitch what wants to be coveted for nothin’ but being born, cryin’ bout the silver spoon what should've been yers. Now look at ye cryin’.
Boo! Boo! What’re y’to do? Look at ye. Look at ye. Will y’kill me? Will ye? Will y’kill me like y’done that gull?
I didn’t--

head_text.subj: WHAT CHANGED THE WIND ON US

text: Damn you!
‘TWAS YE WHAT DAMNED US, DOG! ‘TWAS YE! Will y’do what y’wish y’done to ol’ Winslow?
Would ye best me then? If y’break, I win. If I break ye, I still win.

I always win because yer less a man than I -- and them’s the rules of nature. Them’s truth. I am truth. I make the truth as I see fit. Me. And the truth is that yer a nothin’, Tommy-Tom-Tom. A nothing but a dog what thinks he’s the master when he pulls on his master’s leash. Well if you pull on my leash, I'll choke ye, Thomas Howard, I‘ll strangle ye, fer Winslow were right: You’re A DOG,

head_text.subj: OLD AND YOUNG ATTACK EACH OTHER AT THE SAME TIME

text: EACH OTHERS’ THROATS! EYES BULGE.  90. OLD GRINS WILDLY... YOUNG GRINS BACK... YOUNG STARTS KICKING OLD IN HIS BAD LEG... OLD CRUMBLES TO THE GROUND -- he tries to get up... YOUNG KICKS OLD IN THE SPINE... OLD’S FOREHEAD SMACKS AGAINST THE FLOOR. HARD. It bleeds.
